title: Photographer removes smartphones from portraits to show how lonely we have become
text:
Many of the pictures show intimate moments where the opportunity for human connection has been lost

We like to think of technology a connecting us, allowing us to stay in contact with people anywhere in the world with just a few taps on a screen.

But is the ability to communicate with anyone at any time causing us to neglect the people who are right in front of us?

In a poignant series of portraits, US photographer Eric Pickersgill turns a mirror on our tech-obsessed society, revealing the loneliness that lies within.

Many of the pictures show intimate moments where the opportunity for human connection has been lost because the subjects are engrossed in their devices.

In an eerie twist, the devices themselves have been removed from the scenes, emphasising the emptiness of the situation.

"The joining of people to devices has been rapid and unalterable," said Pickersgill.

"Despite the obvious benefits that these advances in technology have contributed to sq1`ociety, the social and physical implications are slowly revealing themselves.

"Personal devices are shifting behaviours while simultaneously blending into the landscape by taking form as being one with the body."

He describes the smartphone as a "phantom limb" that is often used to signal busyness and unapproachability to strangers.

However, it also exists as an addictive force that encourages people to split their attention between those who are physically with them and those who are not.

"The photographs represent reenactments of scenes that I experience daily," added Pickersgill.

"We have learned to read the expression of the body while someone is consuming a device and when those signifiers are activated it is as if the device can be seen taking physical form without the object being present."
